text: hey everyone tight I sleep tan oh here
the Internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for review we got to talk
about some music makes me excited the
new panopticon's record roads to the
north these guys are a Kentucky metal
band and do not ask me why I'm reviewing
so much metal I'm reviewing it because
it's good and I'm specifically reviewing
this project because I think it's one of
the most interesting long-running
best-kept secrets in the Kentucky music
scene the band is actually sole member
Austin lund who is an incredible
multi-instrumentalist not only bringing
the foundation of metal to the table
with guitars and drums and vocals but
also bringing woodwinds and strings and
a plethora of other instrumentation a
pretty ambitious undertaking however
when I listened to the project's last
full-length LP Kentucky what I
understand to be a bit of a concept
album about Kentucky's coal mining
history I reacted to it a little
negatively because I I think I heard the
second track off of this thing and right
at the start that was a terribly
incorporated either tin whistle or
recorder at the very start of the song
that sounded awful
imagine that soaring over these blast
beats and harsh guitars it was not a
pretty sight however I still walked away
from this record being kind of enamored
with the aesthetic of the band bringing
black metal together with folk music not
anything entirely new but it is
something that some of my favorite black
metal bands do like over and Agalloch
however in Austin Lunz neck of the woods
folk music is something totally
different than it is to over folk music
is American folk music it is bluegrass
so occasionally on these tracks you have
fiddle solos you have banjo and it's
actually pretty nice the folk
instrumentation the acoustic
instrumentation on this record at times
make it pretty easy listen even for
people who aren't really fans of metal
music but throughout a lot of the black
metal moments on this record there's a
really strong element of melody the
harshness on these songs doesn't really
come without an element
sweetness their tracks on this record
that are pure bluegrass like the first
song in this three song series called
the long road it's nothing but plucked
guitars and banjos in every direction of
fiery fiddle solo it's really speedy
dynamic edge-of-your-seat kind of track
even though it's entirely acoustic the
ending of the song isn't the best in the
world because it seems the transition
right into one of the harshest most
pummeling intros on the entire record
and even though I do like these two
styles these two genres that are being
represented here and I think they're
being represented well there is a
serious shift in tone from the end of
this track to the beginning of the next
track and then there's the song
Norwegian Nights which is kind of a very
downtrodden sad despair filled
singer-songwriter track with just
fiddles and guitars that are overcome
with misery and are playing very slow
and the vocals are maybe my least
favorite thing about the track they're
just so cold they're just so
lifeless I'm sure it was intentional to
an extent but even though these vocals
rubbed me the wrong way a little bit
I still see this as a very essential
track in the tracklisting it's a really
nice change of pace a nice piece of
counterpoint from the harder and heavier
songs on this record which are
essentially the crux of the album these
epic twisted adventurous black metal
tracks that reach up to 9 12 minutes
have tons of extra instrumentation woven
into them the first track kicks off of
the flurry of drums and guitars and all
these bleeding fiddles like bleeding
like a sheep I actually find that the
fiddles bring another piece of chaotic
beauty to the the chaotic beauty I
typically find in black metal that I
think is great there's also a really
nice chunky heavy thematic riff that
breaks up these more melodic fiddleback
parts and there's some fiery guitar
solos on the song too and throughout the
entire record as well it's really fast
sweet picking really great sense of
melody and all this stuff this
incredibly riveting stuff happens only
the first four minutes of the song
there's five more minutes every single
track on this
LP no matter how long it is is
incredibly multifaceted dynamic always
progressing always changing like the
track the long road part two which
toward the end of the song it progresses
into this really chill laid-back subtle
progressive rock passage with this great
chord progression the rhythm of this
part just feel so off kilter and yet
it's just so relaxed and as the song
continues it gets a bit of a post rock
vibe with these ethereal soaring guitars
and during the picture and this
post-rock feel continues on to the intro
of the next track it's just so nice to
have this long span of beautiful rock
instrumentation to sort of complement
the harsher parts on this record because
even though they are great and I do like
them they are so unrelenting partially
because the production is so rough not
so rough that it's like darkthrone
Transylvanian hunger level but the drums
the guitars the strings it can all feel
a little claustrophobic and a lot of the
time the vocals are kind of buried
however the recording limitations on
this record don't really stop paying
opticon from incorporating to some
really grim or beautiful subtleties into
these songs like at the end of the long
road three where we get this black metal
style vocal and death metal style vocal
double up the second track off of this
LP starts with a really beautiful
gorgeous acoustic interlude which
progresses into this anthemic marching
black metal hymnal that i think is
actually really invigorating and kind of
uplifting the song gives off this
immense vibe of glory and power and then
there is the last track on the LP which
is maybe the most cinematic and
climactic on the entire record I mean
some illustrious instrumentation on this
thing strings bells it's like some Lord
of the Rings level
this moment in the song really could
have legitimately been placed into a
really huge and expensive soundtrack and
would have sounded great but this is
just one smidge in the song I mean the
rest of the track is good as well but
this is just serious highlight I love
black metal that can bring a sense of
magnificence to the table and this
album definitely does that this album
feels more victorious than the bloodiest
and most righteous battle ever fought
there's so much going for it that
harkens back to the black metal
tradition but the fact that this album
is so influenced by American folk music
and bluegrass just gives it a different
melodic sense plus you have so much
variety on this record and it all comes
together so well for the most part it is
a little long-winded and there are a
couple tracks that I felt like paled in
comparison to others like in silence
which i think is maybe the most
disjointed song on the entire LP but I
was still pretty wowed and amazed by the
material that was put in front of me on
this LP I'm feeling a strongly to like 9
on this thing transition if you've given
this record to listen what did you think
of it did you love it did you hate it
why what do you think I should review
next and that's it Anthony Fantana
panoptic on forever
